text: the personal financial planner is
basically a spreadsheet on steroids it's
designed to help someone track the
consequences of the decisions they make
of the way they live their life the
level at which they want to live uh the
places they want to live the number of
houses they want to have down to things
like uh how many people do you plan to
invite over to your home every year so
the the notion of it was to help
students get away from the compounded
growth phenomena well I'm smarter in the
world I'll make 15% a year on my assets
and life will be good it was really to
help them track through a lot of the
decisions that you make on a day-to-day
basis where you don't even think about
the consequences I mean the cost of your
Starbucks uh you know the latte versus
the Dunkin Donuts is three bucks a day
time 250 is that's $750 a year
compounded for that turns into real
money but it's also decisions like uh
the consequences of different daycare
options or baby care infant care options
so what we tried to do is build in some
reasonable assumptions about the cost of
these things and simply let the students
check some boxes I'm going to have two
children no I'm going to have one child
what's the difference between two and
one child am I going to pay for college
am I going to pay for their
wedding so many of the students
expressed at least during the Heyday
well I'll go out make a lot of money and
I'll retire at 45 well it turns out that
if you really live in New York have your
home in the Hamptons uh have a nanny for
each child that you have and you don't
put a lot of money away uh you're not
going to retire at 45 you may not ever
retire uh you may be a greeter at
Walmart and the personal financial
planner is simply a way to help the
students
see the consequences of those choices
